newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada T-bills open little changed, seen in range.
newsitem.headline: Canada T-bills open little changed, seen in range.

text.p: Canadian T-bills opened little changed on Thursday, amid a lack of significant Canadian economic data, with the market remaining focused on the next likely move in U.S. interest rates, dealers said.

"The market is still looking forward to the FOMC at the latter part of May here. Until that time I see the market in a trading range," said Doug Sannuto, managing director of Canada cash markets with Bank of Montreal.
Canada's three-month when-issued T-bill softened to yield 3.10 percent from 3.09 percent at the close of trading on Wednesday.

Canadian T-bills this week have traded largely on varying speculation about whether the U.S. Federal Reserve's rate-setting open market committee will hike rates when it meet on May 20. A Fed tightening is seen putting pressure on the Bank of Canada to follow suit in order to defend the strength of the Canadian dollar.

In other prices, the six-month when-issued T-bill traded with a yield of 3.50 percent, unchanged from the close of trading on Wednesday. The one-year T-bill softened to yield 4.10 percent from 4.09 percent.

The call loan rate traded at 3.15 percent, in the upper half of Bank of Canada's 2.75-3.25 percent target range. Dealers said the rise in the call loan rate was due to normal settlement pressures from Tuesday's weekly T-bill auction.
